newsitem.title: USA: Centerior Q3 hurt by cooler weather.
newsitem.headline: Centerior Q3 hurt by cooler weather.

text.p: Centerior Energy Corp said Tuesday cooler weather in the third quarter of 1996 lowered revenues by $38 million, or $0.17 a share.
Weather-normalized retail kilowatt-hour sales for the quarter increased 1.4 percent, which produced revenues of $0.02 a share.

Earnings for the quarter ended September 30 were $73.5 million, or $0.50 a share, compared to $108.9 million, or $0.74 a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenues were $727.1 million this quarter, compared to $739.6 million in the third quarter of last year.

"This summer was not nearly as hot as last summer," said Robert Farling, Centerior's chairman, president and chief executive officer. "But when you remove the variation due to weather, our sales showed improvement."
The end of regulatory accounting measures in late 1995 combined with additional revenue from the April 1996 rate increase also reduced net earnings by $0.10 a share in the third quarter.
Third-quarter results were also hurt by a charge against earnings for the planned sale or disposal of excess inventory due to efforts to streamline the company's supply chain organization.
The charge resulted in a pre-tax earnings reduction of $14 million, or $0.06 a share, when comparing the 1996 period with the 1995 period.
In September, Centerior agreed to merge with Ohio Edison Co to form a new holding company named FirstEnergy Corp. The companies hope to complete the merger by the end of 1997.
